Housing Shortage Crisis in Hattiesburg: The
Case for Workforce Housing Development
A White Paper on Affordable Housing Needs in Hattiesburg, Mississippi

Executive Summary
Bottom Line Up Front: Mississippi faces a severe housing shortage with only 59 affordable
homes per 100 extremely low-income households, while Hattiesburg's 13,110+ University of
Southern Mississippi students, healthcare workers earning $39.77/hour average, and essential
workers struggle to find affordable housing in a market where 66% of extremely low-income
renters spend over half their income on housing.
The housing crisis in Hattiesburg, Mississippi reflects a broader national emergency that
demands immediate action. With 102,509 extremely low-income renter households statewide
and only 59 affordable units per 100 households who need them, Mississippi ranks among states
with significant housing shortages. In Hattiesburg specifically, this translates to critical gaps for
workforce populations including 8,100+ USM students living off-campus (81% of total enrollment),
healthcare professionals averaging $39.77 hourly wages, and essential workers whose salaries of
$22.17/hour average cannot compete with rising rental costs of $917-$1,160 monthly.
This white paper documents the scope of housing shortage nationally, regionally, and locally,
analyzing cost burden impacts on target demographics and presenting the economic case for
innovative workforce housing solutions using Structural Insulated Panel (SIP) construction to
address documented market needs.
